AIDS Not Simply a Disease of the Young, Drug-Addicted
DOC.TEXT: T. Franklin Williams, a geriatrics physician, is director of the National Institute on Aging, one of the 13 institutes that comprise the National Institutes of Health of the Department of Health and Human Services.

The speed with which society has responded to the AIDS epidemic is heartening, yet there is one group that society has not begun to attend to in terms of its risk: older Americans. The fact is, 10 percent of all reported cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome have involved people aged 50 and over. And more older people are believed to be infected, although not yet experiencing symptoms. With increased age comes a decline in immune system functions, making older people more susceptible to a variety of illnesses such as cancers and infections. Because of these changes in immune function, AIDS may affect older people differently than it does the young. Data from the Centers for Disease Control suggests that most older people infected with the AIDS virus have developed disease symptoms more quickly than younger patients. The older population also receives the highest rate of blood transfusions. Blood banks now assure safer blood products than before 1985, when the public blood supply was not yet being screened for the virus. By then, however, many older people had already been exposed to possibly contaminated transfusions. As a result, blood transfusions are the second most common cause of AIDS in people over 50 (after sexual contact). Moreover, no one knows how many people received infected blood and are now unknowingly infecting spouses or sexual partners. Older AIDS patients who have early symptoms also risk going undiagnosed. Because early symptoms of AIDS, such as fatigue, loss of appetite and swollen glands, are similar to other more common illnesses, many people _ including health professionals _ may dismiss them as minor ailments. Medical experts predict that a cure or vaccine against AIDS is not likely to be found in the near future. So preventing the spread of AIDS will very much depend on behavioral changes, such as using condoms when sexually involved with someone other than a mutually faithful, uninfected partner. Prevention also begins with education. AIDS is not spread by casual contact, but rather through sexual relations, use of infected needles and blood transfusions. Reliable, up-to-date information is available from many sources. The Public Health Service sent a brochure, ``Understanding AIDS,'' to every home in the country. Call the National AIDS Hotline, 1-800-342-AIDS for another copy; other hotlines also can answer specific questions. Researchers are working to understand AIDS and how to treat people who are infected. Treatment for the symptoms usually involves some drug therapy, such as AZT (azidothymidine), which currently is being used in many patients to prolong life. Other promising drugs are also being tested. People exposed to the virus should stay in touch with a doctor who is well-informed about the latest research. For help finding an expert, call a medical school's infectious disease department or the National AIDS Hotline. You can make a valuable contribution by offering to help groups in your community who work with AIDS patients. Many operate on a shoestring and depend heavily on individual contributions of time and money. These groups include the American Red Cross, March of Dimes, Boys Clubs and Girls Clubs, and the local YMCA. Their phone numbers are listed in your directory, and they will be glad to tell you how to get involved with education, fund-raising drives or volunteer programs. In the years ahead, individuals willing to offer their services to AIDS patients will be increasingly needed. Volunteers can contribute a great deal without endangering their health. For example, as people with AIDS become more disabled, they have trouble meeting their daily needs; they appreciate help with shopping, cooking meals, or just regular visits for talking. For more information on volunteer programs, call your health department or the National AIDS Hotline.
